olygeo.parser package¶

Submodules¶

olygeo.parser.ast_geo module¶

Data classes for the geometry Abstract Syntax Tree (AST), where the results of parsing are stored

class olygeo.parser.ast_geo.SentenceList(left, right)¶

Bases: object

A list (tree) of sentences

class olygeo.parser.ast_geo.Sentence(things)¶

Bases: object

A sentence, which may have several statements

class olygeo.parser.ast_geo.Statement¶

Bases: object

A statement, which can contain several relations

class olygeo.parser.ast_geo.ObjectBoolAdj(adj)¶

Bases: object

A boolean adjective that can apply to a shape

class olygeo.parser.ast_geo.AdjectiveList(adj_list)¶

Bases: object

A list of adjectives that can apply to a shape

class olygeo.parser.ast_geo.Relation(rel, objects)¶

Bases: object

A relation that specifies a constraint based on several objecs

e.g. ABC is an acute triangle

class olygeo.parser.ast_geo.Verb(rel, objects)¶

Bases: object

A relation lacking a noun to complete it

Examples

>>> apply_parser(meets(), "meets $A$ and $B$ at $C$ and $D$").value
Verb[meets, [Multi[[Reference[Point[A], AdjList[[None]]], Reference[Point[B], AdjList[[None]]]]], Multi[[Point[C], Point[D]]]]]
class olygeo.parser.ast_geo.Distance(point_1, point_2)¶

Bases: object

A distance between two points

class olygeo.parser.ast_geo.CompareRelation(rel, left, right)¶

Bases: olygeo.parser.ast_geo.Relation

A relation between two objects, usually distances

Examples

>>> apply_parser(compare_relation(), "$AB<CD=EF$").value
Relation[Relation[Distance[Point[A], Point[B]] < Distance[Point[C], Point[D]]] = Distance[Point[E], Point[F]]]

olygeo.parser.lex_geo module¶

The core module for tokenizing geometry problems.

class olygeo.parser.lex_geo.Tags¶

Bases: enum.Enum

Tags for Tokens

class olygeo.parser.lex_geo.Modes¶

Bases: enum.Enum

Different lexing modes

olygeo.parser.lex_geo.keywords = ['let', 'be', 'a', 'an', 'the', 'and', 'quadrilateral', 'triangle', 'hexagon', 'circle', 'point', 'points', 'convex', 'acute', 'obtuse', 'midpoint', 'of', 'passing through', 'meets', 'at']¶

All keywords with respect to lexing. Other plain words are ignored

olygeo.parser.lex_geo.aux_reserved = ['.', ',']¶

Auxilary list of reserved words in addition to keywords

olygeo.parser.lex_geo.lex_string(string)¶

Lex a geometry string into tokens, including math

olygeo.parser.lex_geo.lex_case(case)¶

For testing, lex a single case

olygeo.parser.lex_geo.pp_lex(lex)¶

Pretty-prints a list of tokens in human-readable form

olygeo.parser.lex_geo.test_math_lexing()¶

Unit tests the lexing of math

olygeo.parser.lexer module¶

Provides a single function to tokenize based on a given grammar.

Modified from imp-interpreter.

olygeo.parser.lexer.lex(characters, modes, mode_types, start_mode, tag_start, tag_end, case_insensitive=False)¶

Tokenize a string

Parameters

  • characters (str | list of chars) – The string to tokenize

  • modes – Main specification of the grammar

    Should be a dictionary from modes to lists of pairs (regex, effect) such as

    {
    mode_1: [
        (regex_1, tag_1),
        (regex_2, tag_2),
        (regex_3, mode_1)
    ],
    mode_2: [ ... ]
}

    If effect is a member of mode_types, such as with (regex_3, mode_1) here, the mode transitions to to the mode. Otherwise a token emitted with the matched text and the given tag.

olygeo.parser.parse_geo module¶

The core module for parsing geometry as a sentence

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.print_pass(tag=None)¶

Return a function to Process a Parser with that acts as a print statement

Use to print the value of a parser without affecting it

Example

>>> apply_parser((point() ^ print_pass("first point")) + point(), "$P$ $Q$")
first point Point[P]
Result(
  [Point[P], Point[Q]]
2)
olygeo.parser.parse_geo.article()¶

Return a parser for any article (‘a’, ‘an’, or ‘the’)

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.keyword(key)¶

Return a parser for a keyword

Notes

A keyword is any word that affects parsing. Other words outside math get ignored

Raises

AssertionError – If key is not listed as a keyword in olygeo.parser.lex_geo

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.point()¶

Return a parser for a point

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.segment()¶

Return a parser for a segment

Notes

A segment is two consecutive points. Segments are differentiated from distances by context

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.distance()¶

Return a parser for a distance

Notes

A distance is two consecutive points. Segments are differentiated from distances by context

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.compare_relation()¶

Return a parser for a compare relation

Notes

A compare relation is an inequality between two distances

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.polygon()¶

Return a parser for any polygon

Notes

A polygon consists of 3 to 8 consecutive points

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.obj()¶

Return a parser for any object, such as $omega$

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.reference()¶

Return a parser for an object reference.

Notes

A reference is any shape, possibly combined with an article, adjectives, or gerund adjectives

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.multi(parser, singular=None, plural=None)¶

Return a parser for multiple of another parser.

Parameters

  • parser – The parser that can be repeated.

  • singular, plural – Singular and plural forms of the name of the object

Examples

>>> apply_parser(multi_point(), "$P$").value
Multi[[Point[P]]]
>>> apply_parser(multi_point(), "point $P$ and $Q$").value
Multi[[Point[P], Point[Q]]]
>>> apply_parser(multi_point(), "$P$, $Q$, and $R$").value
Multi[[Point[P], Point[Q], Point[R]]]
olygeo.parser.parse_geo.multi_point()¶

Return a parser for multiple of a point.

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.multi_reference()¶

Return a parser for multiple of a reference.

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.math()¶

Return a parser for any math item.

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.thing()¶

Return a parser to match roughly anything: math or any reserved word.

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.any_of(words, tag)¶

Return a parser for any token with a given tag and given value set.

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.any_keyword(words)¶

Return a parser for any reserved word with value from a given set.

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.midpoint()¶

Return a parser for the relational adjective “midpoint.”

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.relational_adj()¶

Return a parser for a relational adjective.

Notes

A relational adjective is an adjective that specifies a constraint on a shape given some other shapes

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.passing_through()¶

Return a parser for the gerund adjective “passing through”.

Notes

The gerund adjective “passing through” specifies that the subject shape intersects the object shape at at least one point

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.gerund_adj()¶

Return a parser for a gerund adjective.

Notes

A gerund adjective is an adjective ending in “-ing” that can be tacked on after a shape

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.meets()¶

Return a parser for the verb “meets.”

Notes

The verb meets specifies that the subject shapes intersects its first object at its second object

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.verb()¶

Return a parser for any verb, which can be used in a verb statement.

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.bool_adj()¶

Return a parser for a boolean adjective that can describe a shape.

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.shape_adj()¶

Return a parser for a single adjective that can describe a shape.

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.shape_adj_list()¶

Return a parser for a list of adjectives that can describe a shape.

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.let_statement()¶

Return a parser for a let statement.

Notes

A let statement has a single subject shape which receives one or more adjectives which specify constraints

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.verb_statement()¶

Return a parser for a verb statement.

Notes

A verb statement has a single subject shape which may act on any number of objects with a specific action

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.stmt()¶

Return a parser for a statement.

Notes

A statement directly specifies one or more constraints and can only be combined to AND components together

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.sentence()¶

Return a parser for a sentence.

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.sentence_list()¶

Return a parser for a list of sentences.

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.geo_parser()¶

Return a parser for sentences that spans the whole input token list.

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.parse_geo(tokens)¶

Parse tokens from a geometry string.

Parameters

tokens – the tokens to parse

Returns

Return type

AST

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.test_math_parsing()¶

Test the parsing of all math sequences

olygeo.parser.parse_geo.apply_parser(parser, string)¶

Parse a string with a specific parser

Parameters

  • parser – the name of the parser to test

  • string (str) – single string to tokenize and test

Returns

Return type

AST

olygeo.parser.parser module¶

Provides classes to create a hardcoded grammar to parse with

Modified from imp-interpreter.

Wrap any string or non-sequence into a list

olygeo.parser.parser.listify(ls)¶

class olygeo.parser.parser.Result(value, pos)¶

Bases: object

Result of a partial parse

Parameters

  • value – The captured value from the partial parse

  • pos (int) – The number of characters parsed to get this result

class olygeo.parser.parser.IgnoredResult(pos)¶

Bases: olygeo.parser.parser.Result

A Result that is ignored when Concat’d to something else

class olygeo.parser.parser.ParserPair(left, right)¶

Bases: object

A pair of parsers

Serves only to deal with left-associative __mul__ operator for Parser

Parameters

left, right – The parsers

class olygeo.parser.parser.Parser¶

Bases: abc.ABC

A parser that updates position when parsing and gives Results

Notes

Observe that combining operators follows operator preference https://docs.python.org/3/reference/expressions.html#operator-precedence, notably:

  1. |: Alternate

  2. ^: Process

  3. +: Concat

  4. *: Exp

  5. **: ExpSep

abstract __call__(tokens, pos)¶

Call self as a function.

__add__(other)¶

Concatenate two Parser objects together (+)

__mul__(other)¶

Create an Exp

Notes

This uses a triadic combination

parser1() * separator() * cumulation_function()

__pow__(other)¶

Create an ExpSep

Notes

This uses a triadic combination

parser1() ** separator() ** cumulation_function()

__or__(other)¶

Take the Alternate of two Parser objects (|)

__xor__(function)¶

Take the Process of a Parser object and a function

class olygeo.parser.parser.Ignored(parser)¶

Bases: olygeo.parser.parser.Parser

A Parser which ignores returned results

This only makes sense in the context of Concat, which will not append results from an Ignored.

Parameters

parser (Parser) – the parser whose results are to be ignored

__call__(tokens, pos)¶
Returns

The result of the parser, except whose value is ignored

Return type

IgnoredResult

class olygeo.parser.parser.Concat(left, right)¶

Bases: olygeo.parser.parser.Parser

A Parser matching two parsers in a row.

Equivalent to XY in regex

Parameters

left, right (Parser) – The parsers on the left and the right to be concatenated together

__call__(tokens, pos)¶
Returns

The results of the left and right parsers appended to each other. This will return a single list, not a nested list based on associativity

Return type

Result

class olygeo.parser.parser.Alternate(left, right)¶

Bases: olygeo.parser.parser.Parser

A Parser matching either one parser or the other.

Equivalent to X|Y in regex

Parameters

left, right – The parsers, one of which must be matched for the Alternate to match

__call__(tokens, pos)¶
Returns

The result of the parser which matches, with the first parser taking precedence over the second.

Return type

Result

class olygeo.parser.parser.Opt(parser, ignored_on_unmatch=False)¶

Bases: olygeo.parser.parser.Parser

A Parser matching 1 or 0 of a parser.

Equivalent to X? in regex

Parameters

parser (Parser) – The parser which may be matched

failure(pos)¶
Returns

A Result with None value

Return type

Result

__call__(tokens, pos)¶

The result of the parser if matched, or the result of failure() otherwise

class olygeo.parser.parser.Rep(parser)¶

Bases: olygeo.parser.parser.Parser

A Parser that matches any number of another parser (including 0)

Equivalent to X* in regex

Parameters

parser (Parser) – The parser to be matches a number of times

__call__(tokens, pos)¶
Returns

A list of all the results matched by parser

Return type

list of Result

class olygeo.parser.parser.RepMulti(parser, min_reps=1, max_reps=inf)¶

Bases: olygeo.parser.parser.Parser

A Parser that matches another parser a number of times within a range

Equivalent to X{min_reps, max_reps} in regex

Parameters

  • parser (Parser) – The parser to be matches a number of times

  • min_reps, max_reps (int) – The minimum and maximum number of repetitions, inclusive

__call__(tokens, pos)¶

Call self as a function.

class olygeo.parser.parser.Process(parser, function)¶

Bases: olygeo.parser.parser.Parser

A Parser that applies a function to the Result of a parser

Parameters

  • parser (Parser) – The parser to match

  • function – The function to be applied to the result

__call__(tokens, pos)¶
Returns

function applied to the result of parser except when the result is None, at which point None is returned

Return type

Result

class olygeo.parser.parser.Phrase(parser)¶

Bases: olygeo.parser.parser.Parser

A Parser that matches only when matching the full input stream of tokens

Equivalent to X$ in regex

Parameters

parser (Parser) – Parser to match fully

__call__(tokens, pos)¶
Returns

  • The result of the parser if successful and its match lasts the full

  • input stream, otherwise None

class olygeo.parser.parser.Exp(parser, separator)¶

Bases: olygeo.parser.parser.Parser

A Parser that matches another parser joined by a specific parser

Equivalent to A(BA)* in regex but avoids left recursion

Parameters

  • parser (Parser) – Main parser

  • separator (Process) – Parser that matches token sequences that join the sequence. The function of separator should take left and right values and return a new value. A sane choice of function would be:

    lambda left, right: ListAST(left, right)
__call__(tokens, pos)¶
Returns

  • The result of the function from separator applied left to right

  • across all matches of parser

class olygeo.parser.parser.ExpSep(parser, separator, sepfunc)¶

Bases: olygeo.parser.parser.Parser

A Parser that matches another parser joined by a specific parser

Similar to Exp, but it also passes the matches of the separator into the joining function

Equivalent to A(BA)* in regex but avoids left recursion

Parameters

  • parser (Parser) – Main parser

  • separator (Process) – Parser that matches token sequences that join the sequence. The function of separator should take left, sep, and right values and return a new value. A sane choice of function would be:

    lambda left, sep, right: ListAST(left, right, join=sep)
__call__(tokens, pos)¶
Returns

  • The result of the function from separator applied left to right

  • across all matches of parser and separator

class olygeo.parser.parser.ZeroWidth¶

Bases: olygeo.parser.parser.Parser

A parser which always matches and just moves on with an empty match of None.

This continues at the same position, so it does effectively nothing but is not ignored in Concat.

This is effectively just for convenience.

Warning

Only use at the end of an Alternate. Never repeat

__call__(tokens, pos)¶

Call self as a function.

olygeo.parser.parser.indented(string, amount=2, spacer=' ', sep='\n')¶

Return a string indented at each line by a certain amount.

By default, indents each line (determined by \n linefeeds) by 2 spaces.

olygeo.parser.parser.star(f)¶

Convert a function to take a list of args instead of *args in sequence

Notes

See https://stackoverflow.com/q/21892989.

olygeo.parser.test module¶

Provides functions for testing functions

olygeo.parser.test.test(func, get_parts=None)¶

Test a function on specific parts using the training data

Parameters

  • func – The function to test

  • get_parts – A function to split each case into sub-cases to independently test

    Default: just test each whole test case without splitting
